abstract.p: Ken Johnson reviews Seth Michael Forman's paintings at Adam Baumgold gallery (S)

block.p: Something odd is happening in each of Seth Michael Forman's medium-small, tenderly made oil paintings. A clown submits to execution by a man with a big ax. A woman in a flowing black robe kneels in prayer at the entrance to a cave, a tiny, pitch-black baby hovering before her. A Boschian creature with a bulbous, pink, four-legged body and a man's head contemplates the jawbone of a large animal. Two men sing over the body of a dead pig.
These and other events are staged in gloomily Romantic, bucolic or wilderness settings that call Albert Pinkham Ryder to mind.

Something odd is happening in each of Seth Michael Forman's medium-small, tenderly made oil paintings. A clown submits to execution by a man with a big ax. A woman in a flowing black robe kneels in prayer at the entrance to a cave, a tiny, pitch-black baby hovering before her. A Boschian creature with a bulbous, pink, four-legged body and a man's head contemplates the jawbone of a large animal. Two men sing over the body of a dead pig.
These and other events are staged in gloomily Romantic, bucolic or wilderness settings that call Albert Pinkham Ryder to mind.

Mr. Forman's dreamlike scenarios are eerie, comical and tantalizing. One senses some particular meaning close to but elusively below the surface. Perhaps like tarot cards, the images represent stages on an inner journey of self-transformation.
